column1: #Text=The polycrystalline samples of undoped BiFeO3 (referred to as BFO) and Dy doped Bi0.9Dy0.1FeO3 (referred to as BDFO) were synthesized using standard solid state reaction technique [14].

#Text=To prepare the bulk polycrystalline samples, the calcined powders were pressed into pellets using a uniaxial hydraulic press and sintered at 825oC for 5 hours at heating rate of 3 oC per minute.
#Text=The pellets were ground again into powder materials.

#Text=The nanoparticles were fabricated directly from these bulk powder materials using the ultrasonic probe dispersion technique with varying amount of sonication time by the application of ultrasonic energy generated from a probe [16].
#Text=For the synthesis of nanoparticles, a portion of the micrometer sized powder was subsequently mixed with isopropanol.

#Text=We then put the mixtures of isopropanol and powder with a mass percentage of ∼0.5% [16] into an ultrasonic probe and sonicated the solutions for 30, 60 and 90 minutes respectively, for three different samples.
#Text=After around six hours, ∼40% of the mass was collected as supernatant and was used for characterization.
#Text=X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed using a diffractometer with CuKα (λ = 1.5418 A˚ ) radiation to study the crystalline structures of the as synthesized materials.

#Text=The magnetization vs. applied magnetic field (M-H) hysteresis loops of BFO, BDFO bulk and nanoparticles were investigated using a Superconducting Quantum Interference Device (SQUID) Magnetometer (Quantum Design MPMS-XL7, USA).
#Text=The temperature dependent magnetization measurements were investigated both at zero field cooling (ZFC) and field cooling (FC) processes.
#Text=To measure electrical properties of nanoparticles, pellets were prepared by pressing the powders using a hydraulic press and annealing at 750oC with high heating rate (20oC/min) [22].
#Text=A ferroelectric loop tracer in conjunction with an external amplifier (10 kV) was used to trace the leakage current density and ferroelectric polarization of the pellet shaped samples.
#Text=Finally, ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-Vis DRS mode) of the samples were measured by a UV-visible spectrometer (UV-2600, SHIMADZU).
